required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Family Based Prevention of Alcohol and Risky Sex for Older Teens
clinical_study.official_title: Web-based Family Prevention of Alcohol and Risky Sex for Older Teens

lead_sponsor.agency: Pacific Institute for Research and Evaluation

clinical_study.source: Pacific Institute for Research and Evaluation

brief_summary.textblock: An online, interactive web-based program for older teens and their parents is designed to address teen alcohol use and teen relationships. The parent-teen dyad both participate in the web-based program and engage in off-line discussion activities. This intervention promotes communication skills, refusal skills, and helps teens consider how to make healthy choices. A total of 411 family dyads (one parent, one teen) were recruited.

detailed_description.textblock:
This purpose of this study is to develop an interactive, web-based prevention program for parents and older teens that focuses on teen use of alcohol and teen relationships. The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial.
Specific Aim 1: To adapt two parent-based prevention strategies (Family Matters and Parent Handbook) to provide a family-based approach for addressing older teen alcohol related risk behaviors and sexual risk behaviors and sex in combination with alcohol use (hereafter called alcohol and/or sexual risk behaviors) using the web as the program delivery mode.
Specific Aim 2: To test whether exposure to the program leads to expected changes in targeted teen beliefs and behaviors, including reductions in alcohol and/or sexual risk behaviors.
Specific Aim 3: To examine whether program effects on teen alcohol and/or sexual risk behaviors are mediated through changes in intermediate program targeted beliefs (parents and teen) and behaviors (e.g., parent-teen--communication). Program fidelity and process measures may also mediate these outcomes.
Phase I integrates and adapts the two parent-based approaches and creates a web-based interactive delivery of materials. Expert panels, focus groups, and usability assessments will inform the process. Phase II is an RCT with 400 families with the web-based intervention. Surveys will be conducted at baseline, and for three follow-up periods (6, 12, & 18 months). Analyses will examine teen outcomes related to alcohol and/or sexual risk behaviors. Changes in mediators directly impacted by the program for both teens and parents will be examined. Process and fidelity information will be collected and assessed.
A web-based prevention strategy supporting parents and teens, is significant and timely. Parents and teens will use the internet to make health decisions. This program is uniquely different from other programs be-cause it addresses teens at high risk for alcohol and/or sexual risk behaviors. Further, the strategy involves both parents and teens through an interactive framework. The approach utilizes the strengths of Family Matters which promotes specific exercises and activities between parents and teens and the strengths of the Parent Handbook which addresses issues of importance to this age range.

study_design_info.masking_description: Parents and Teens were either assigned to the full intervention or provided with didactic materials available on the internet. Family is considered the level of participant

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Teens Using Any Alcohol During Past 6 Months
primary_outcome.description: Have you had a drink of alcohol in the past 6 months? (A drink is a glass of wine, a can of beer, a wine cooler, a shot glass of liquor, or a mixed drink). (Response category yes=1/no=0). Range is 0-1. More frequent drinking is a worse outcome.

primary_outcome.measure: Frequency of Teen Alcohol Use Over Most Recent 30 Days Within Past 6 Months
primary_outcome.description: Over the past 30 days, how many times have you had a drink of alcohol? (response categories: 0=none, 1=once, 2=2-3 times, 3= once a week, 4=2-3 times a week. Range is 0-4.Higher score is more frequent drinking and a worse outcome.

primary_outcome.measure: Quantity of Alcohol Consumed by Teens on Drinking Days for the Most Recent 30 Days Within the Past Six Months
primary_outcome.description: Over the past 30 days, how many drinks did you usually have on days you drank? (response categories: 0= less than one, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7= more than six). Range is 0-7. Higher scores represent more drinking and worse outcome.

primary_outcome.measure: Count of Teens Who Were Drunk or Very, Very High During the Past 6 Months
primary_outcome.description: Over the past 6 months, how many times have you gotten drunk or very, very high on alcohol? (Response categories: 0=none, 1=once a month, 2=2-3 times a month, 3=once a week, 4= 2-3 times a week, 5=daily or almost daily). Range is 0-5. Higher score represents more drunkenness and a worse outcome.

primary_outcome.measure: Frequency of Parental Approval for Teen Drinking (in Moderation)
primary_outcome.description: How often have you and your parent talked about drinking in moderation is okay (Response categories 1=Never, 2=Occasionally, 3=Sometimes, 4= Often, 5 = Very often). Range is 1-5 and higher scores means more parental approval of teen drinking and is a worse outcome.

primary_outcome.measure: Frequency of Teen- Parent Communications Regarding Sex
primary_outcome.description: Overall, how often you have talked to your parent about sex? (1=Never, 2=Occasionally, 3=Sometimes, 4=Often, 5= Very often). Range 1-5. Higher scores represent a better outcome.

primary_outcome.measure: Frequency of Teen-parent Communications About Specific Sexual Topics
primary_outcome.description: Average frequency created across 4 different sex topics (i. how being in a relationship might divert me from achieving my goals at school, ii. how embarrassing it would be if I caught an STI -sexually transmitted infection, iii. sexual relationships can impact health, iv. how pregnancy would be embarassing) with responses being never=1, occasionally=2, sometimes=3, often=4, very often=5. Range is 4-20 and average created by dividing the score by 4, with higher scores indicating more both topics and higher frequency of discussions taking place.

primary_outcome.measure: Count of Teen-parent Communications Regarding Delaying Sexual Activity
primary_outcome.description: Communications regarding delaying sex based upon three questions with yes=1/no=0 responses summed: Have your parents told you that (i)you should not have sex, (ii)you should not be in a serious relationship while still in high school, (iii)you should not have sex because your religion or values forbid sex outside of marriage. Higher scores indicate more communications about delaying sex. Range is 0-3. Higher scores represent a better outcome.

primary_outcome.measure: Count of Teen-parent Communications Regarding Health Risks Associated With Sex
primary_outcome.description: Parent-teen communications score regarding health risks with sex were based upon two items: discussion that sex can result in pregnancy (y=1/n=0) and sex can result in sexually transmitted infections (y=1/n=0). Range is 0-2. Higher scores represent a better outcome.

Parental rules regarding dating were based upon summing the yes (=1) response to 15 possible rules: parents must meet date, check in/call during date, parents must know destination, parents must know change of plans, address and phone number needed for parties, no dates on school nights, no sex, no sigle dates, curfew, only agreed upon locations, use good judgment, be gentleman/lady, leave if uncomfortable (y=1/n=0). Range is 0-15. Higher scores represent better outcomes.

primary_outcome.measure: Count of Teens Who Have Ever Had Sex Over Their Lifetime
primary_outcome.description: Have you ever had sex (vaginal, oral, or anal)? (responses were yes=1/no=0). Range was 0-1. Higher score is worse outcome risk.

arm_group.description: A web-based intervention consisting of 3 main components (Communication, Alcohol, Relationships) provided to both parents and teens was completed by parents and teens individually. At the end of each component, discussion guidelines were given to promote communications and to offer skill building practices between parent and teen regarding the component topic. Both the parent and teen were required to complete the component and discussion before moving to the next component. Numbers are provided for the number of families
This group was provided with websites where information was available regarding the same topics.

intervention.description: This is a web-based prevention program designed to convey information about alcohol and relationships and the types of choices that they are making regarding these topics. General communications was another core element of the program that provided parents and teens with some key elements of talking to each other.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- One parent and the teen both had to enroll in the study.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Non-English speaking

link.description: Efficacy of a Web-Based Intervention (Smart Choices 4 Teens) for Facilitating Parent-Adolescent Communication About Relationships and Sexuality: Randomized Controlled Trial

results_reference.citation: Byrnes HF, Miller BA, Grube JW, Bourdeau B, Buller DB, Wang-Schweig M, Woodall WG. Prevention of alcohol use in older teens: A randomized trial of an online family prevention program. Psychol Addict Behav. 2019 Feb;33(1):1-14. doi: 10.1037/adb0000442. Epub 2019 Jan 14.

Wang-Schweig M, Miller BA, Buller DB, Byrnes HF, Bourdeau B, Rogers V. Using Panel Vendors for Recruitment Into a Web-Based Family Prevention Program: Methodological Considerations. Eval Health Prof. 2017 Jan 1:163278717742189. doi: 10.1177/0163278717742189. [Epub ahead of print]

Bourdeau B, Miller BA, Byrnes HF, Woodall WG, Buller DB, Grube JW. Efficacy of a Web-Based Intervention (Smart Choices 4 Teens) for Facilitating Parent-Adolescent Communication About Relationships and Sexuality: Randomized Controlled Trial. JMIR Pediatr Parent. 2021 Jun 15;4(2):e19114. doi: 10.2196/19114.

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Pacific Institute for Research and Evaluation

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

participant_flow.recruitment_details: November 2014-November 2015 Recruited national sample from two panel vendors
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: To be eligible, one teen and one parent had to be willing to participate. Enrollment was considered complete after the participants completed consent and baseline surveys. A total of 559 families were eligible and 148 of eligible families declined to participate, leaving a total of 411 families.

group.title: Smart Choices 4 Teens
group.description: A web-based intervention consisting of 3 main components (Communication, Alcohol, Relationships) provided to both parents and teens was completed by parents and teens individually. At the end of each component, discussion guidelines were given to promote communications and to offer skill building practices between parent and teen regarding the component topic. Both the parent and teen were required to complete the component and discussion before moving to the next component. Smart Choices 4 Teens: This is a web-based prevention program designed to convey information about alcohol and relationships and the types of choices that they are making regarding these topics. General communications was another core element of the program that provided parents and teens with some key elements of talking to each other.

group.title: Control Condition
group.description: This group was provided with websites where information was available regarding the same topics.

group.title: Smart Choices 4 Teens
group.description: A web-based intervention consisting of 3 main components (Communication, Alcohol, Relationships) provided to both parents and teens was completed by parents and teens individually. At the end of each component, discussion guidelines were given to promote communications and to offer skill building practices between parent and teen regarding the component topic. Both the parent and teen were required to complete the component and discussion before moving to the next component. Smart Choices 4 Teens: This is a web-based prevention program designed to convey information about alcohol and relationships and the types of choices that they are making regarding these topics. General communications was another core element of the program that provided parents and teens with some key elements of talking to each other.

group.title: Control Condition
group.description: This group was provided with websites where information was available regarding the same topics.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

measure.title: Age
measure.description: parent and teen ages
measure.population: There are two distinct groups in this study: parents and teens. To show the ages for each group, separate rows have been established

measure.title: Sex: Female, Male
measure.population: There is one teen in each group for whom sex is unknown or not specified

measure.title: Ethnicity (NIH/OMB)
Race (NIH/OMB)

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measure.title: Region of Enrollment
measure.description: Nationwide sample to reflect diversity of national population

measure.title: Any Alcohol Use
measure.description: Have you had a drink of alcohol in the past 6 months? (A drink is a glass of wine, a can of beer, a wine cooler, a shot glass of liquor, or a mixed drink).(Response category-1=yes and 0=no)
measure.population: Missing data accounts for discrepancy

measure.title: Frequency of Alcohol Use
measure.description: Over the past 30 days, how many times have you had a drink of alcohol? (response categories: 0=none, 1=once, 2=2-3 times, 3= once a week, 4=2-3 times a week--higher score is more frequent drinking during the past 30 days)
measure.population: Missing data accounts for discrepancy

measure.title: Quantity of alcohol consumed on drinking days
measure.description: Over the past 30 days, how many drinks did you usually have on days you drank? (response categories: 0= less than one, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7= more than six)
measure.population: Missing data accounts for differences in numbers

measure.title: Number of times drunk or very, very high
measure.description: Over the past 6 months, how many times have you gotten drunk or very, very high on alcohol? (Response categories: 0=none, 1=once a month, 2=2-3 times a month, 3=once a week, 4= 2-3 times a week, 5=daily or almost daily).
measure.population: Missing data accounts for discrepancy

measure.title: Parental approval of teen drinking (in moderation)
measure.description: How often have you and your parent talked about drinking in moderation is okay (Response categories 1=Never, 2=Occasionally, 3=Sometimes, 4= Often, 5 = Very often)
measure.population: missing data explain differences in population analyzed

measure.title: Overall communication about sex
measure.description: Overall, how often you have talked to your parent about sex? (1=Never, 2=Occasionally, 3=Sometimes, 4=Often, 5= Very often)
measure.population: 7 cases with missing data

measure.title: Frequency for Topic Specific sexual activity
measure.description: Average frequency created across 4 different sex topics (e.g., how being in a relationship might divert me from achieving my goals at school, how embarrassing it would be if I caught an STI -sexually transmitted infection) with higher scores indicating more topics discussed. Responses were reported on a likert type scale with 1= never, 2=occasionally, 3= sometimes, 4=often, and 5=very often. Scores ranged from 1 to 5.
measure.population: one case missing data for variable

measure.title: Communications regarding delaying sex
measure.description: Communications regarding delaying sex based upon three questions with yes=1/no=0 responses summed: Have your parents told you that (i)you should not have sex, (ii)you should not be in a serious relationship while still in high school, (iii)you should not have sex because your religion or values forbid sex outside of marriage. Higher scores indicate more communications about delaying sex. Scores ranged from 0-3.
measure.population: one case from each arm is missing data on this variable

measure.title: Communication regarding health risks
measure.description: Parent-teen communications score regarding health risks with sex were based upon two items: discussion that sex can result in pregnancy (y=1/n=0) and sex can result in sexually transmitted infections (y=1/n=0). Scores ranged from 0-2.
measure.population: missing data for 4 cases

measure.title: Number of Dating rules
measure.description: Parental rules regarding dating were based upon 15 possible rules (parents must meet the date, check in once during the evening, parents must know destination, change plans-inform parent, address and phone number if going to party, no dates on school nights, no sex, no single dates, curfew, only go to agreed upon locations, use good judgment, be bentleman/lady, leave if uncomfortable, don't let someone domineer you, before sexually active discussion needed) with y=1/n=0 summed across the 15 items. Possible range 0-15.
measure.population: 8 cases have missing data

measure.title: Ever had sex
measure.description: Have you ever had sex (vaginal, oral, or anal)? (responses were yes=1/no=0)
measure.population: Some teens did not answer the question

outcome.title: Number of Teens Using Any Alcohol During Past 6 Months
outcome.description: Have you had a drink of alcohol in the past 6 months? (A drink is a glass of wine, a can of beer, a wine cooler, a shot glass of liquor, or a mixed drink). (Response category yes=1/no=0). Range is 0-1. More frequent drinking is a worse outcome.
outcome.population: Some teens were lost at follow-up

group.title: Smart Choices 4 Teens
group.description: A web-based intervention consisting of 3 main components (Communication, Alcohol, Relationships) provided to both parents and teens was completed by parents and teens individually. At the end of each component, discussion guidelines were given to promote communications and to offer skill building practices between parent and teen regarding the component topic. Both the parent and teen were required to complete the component and discussion before moving to the next component. Smart Choices 4 Teens: This is a web-based prevention program designed to convey information about alcohol and relationships and the types of choices that they are making regarding these topics. General communications was another core element of the program that provided parents and teens with some key elements of talking to each other.

group.title: Assigned Intervention, no Exposures
group.description: Assigned to intervention but had no exposure to alcohol component of the intervention.

group.title: Control Condition
group.description: This group received information that was available on an NIAAA website

measure.title: Number of Teens Using Any Alcohol During Past 6 Months
measure.description: Have you had a drink of alcohol in the past 6 months? (A drink is a glass of wine, a can of beer, a wine cooler, a shot glass of liquor, or a mixed drink). (Response category yes=1/no=0). Range is 0-1. More frequent drinking is a worse outcome.
measure.population: Some teens were lost at follow-up

analysis.groups_desc: 6 month follow-up. Among those assigned to intervention, dosage was assigned as 0 for no exposure, 1 for completing only the communication, and 2 for completing the alcohol component. A probit analysis predicting completion was conducted from baseline measures and an instrumental variable, inverse Mills' ratio (IMR) representing the underlying selection processes was included as a covariate accounting for factors related to program completion. All controls were assigned 0 dosage.
analysis.method_desc: b=-.91, controlling for condition (experimental vs. control) , IMR, baseline measure of outcome variable, teen gender, age, & race.

analysis.groups_desc: 12 month follow-up. Among those assigned to intervention, dosage was assigned as 0 for no exposure, 1 for completing only the communication, and 2 for completing the alcohol component. A probit analysis predicting completion was conducted from baseline measures and an instrumental variable, inverse Mills' ratio (IMR) representing the underlying selection processes was included as a covariate accounting for factors related to program completion. All controls were assigned 0 dosage.
analysis.estimate_desc: Controlling for condition (experimental vs. control) , IMR, baseline measure of outcome variable, teen gender, age, & race.

analysis.groups_desc: 18 month follow-up. Among those assigned to intervention, dosage was assigned as 0 for no exposure, 1 for completing only the communication, and 2 for completing the alcohol component. All controls were assigned 0 dosage.

outcome.title: Frequency of Teen Alcohol Use Over Most Recent 30 Days Within Past 6 Months
outcome.description: Over the past 30 days, how many times have you had a drink of alcohol? (response categories: 0=none, 1=once, 2=2-3 times, 3= once a week, 4=2-3 times a week. Range is 0-4.Higher score is more frequent drinking and a worse outcome.
outcome.population: Missing responses and teens lost at follow-up

Both the parent and teen were required to complete the component and discussion before moving to the next component. outcome.population: The rows represent 3 different follow-up periods and the number of cases analyzed varied because the responses at follow-up varied.

group.title: Smart Choices 4 Teens
group.description: A web-based intervention consisting of 3 main components (Communication, Alcohol, Relationships) provided to both parents and teens was completed by parents and teens individually. At the end of each component, discussion guidelines were given to promote communications and to offer skill building practices between parent and teen regarding the component topic. Both the parent and teen were required to complete the component and discussion before moving to the next component. Smart Choices 4 Teens: This is a web-based prevention program designed to convey information about alcohol and relationships and the types of choices that they are making regarding these topics. General communications was another core element of the program that provided parents and teens with some key elements of talking to each other.

group.title: Assigned Intervention, no Exposure
group.description: This group was assigned to the intervention but had no exposure to the relationship component of the intervention.

group.title: Control Condition
group.description: This group was provided with websites where information was available regarding the same topics.

measure.title: Frequency of Teen- Parent Communications Regarding Sex
measure.description: Overall, how often you have talked to your parent about sex? (1=Never, 2=Occasionally, 3=Sometimes, 4=Often, 5= Very often). Range 1-5. Higher scores represent a better outcome.
measure.population: The rows represent 3 different follow-up periods and the number of cases analyzed varied because the responses at follow-up varied.

analysis.groups_desc: Among those assigned to intervention, dosage was assigned as 0 for no exposure, 1 for completing some of the program, and 2 for completing the relationship component. A probit analysis predicting completion was conducted from baseline measures and an instrumental variable, inverse Mills' ratio (IMR) representing the underlying selection processes was included as a covariate accounting for factors related to program completion. All controls were assigned 0 dosage.
analysis.estimate_desc: controlling for condition (experimental vs. control) , IMR, baseline measure of outcome variable, teen gender, age, & race.

outcome.title: Frequency of Teen-parent Communications About Specific Sexual Topics
outcome.description: Average frequency created across 4 different sex topics (i. how being in a relationship might divert me from achieving my goals at school, ii. how embarrassing it would be if I caught an STI -sexually transmitted infection, iii. sexual relationships can impact health, iv. how pregnancy would be embarassing) with responses being never=1, occasionally=2, sometimes=3, often=4, very often=5. Range is 4-20 and average created by dividing the score by 4, with higher scores indicating more both topics and higher frequency of discussions taking place.
outcome.population: The number analyzed varies across rows because the rows represent different follow-up periods and participation varied across follow-ups.

group.title: Smart Choices 4 Teens
group.description: A web-based intervention consisting of 3 main components (Communication, Alcohol, Relationships) provided to both parents and teens was completed by parents and teens individually. class.title: Frequency of sexual communication at 6 month follow-up
Frequency of sexual communication at 12 month follow-up
Frequency of sexual communication at 18 month follow-up

analysis.groups_desc: Among those assigned to intervention, dosage was assigned as 0 for no exposure, 1 for completing some of the program, and 2 for completing the relationship component. A probit analysis predicting completion was conducted from baseline measures and an instrumental variable, inverse Mills' ratio (IMR) representing the underlying selection processes was included as a covariate accounting for factors related to program completion. All controls were assigned 0 dosage.

outcome.title: Count of Teen-parent Communications Regarding Delaying Sexual Activity
outcome.description: Communications regarding delaying sex based upon three questions with yes=1/no=0 responses summed: Have your parents told you that (i)you should not have sex, (ii)you should not be in a serious relationship while still in high school, (iii)you should not have sex because your religion or values forbid sex outside of marriage. Higher scores indicate more communications about delaying sex. Range is 0-3. Higher scores represent a better outcome.
outcome.population: The three rows represent different follow-up periods and there are different response rates across follow-up periods.

group.title: Smart Choices 4 Teens
group.description: A web-based intervention consisting of 3 main components (Communication, Alcohol, Relationships) provided to both parents and teens was completed by parents and teens individually. measure.description: Communications regarding delaying sex based upon three questions with yes=1/no=0 responses summed: Have your parents told you that (i)you should not have sex, (ii)you should not be in a serious relationship while still in high school, (iii)you should not have sex because your religion or values forbid sex outside of marriage. Higher scores indicate more communications about delaying sex. Range is 0-3. Higher scores represent a better outcome.

analysis.estimate_desc: controlling for condition (experimental vs. control) , IMR, baseline measure of outcome variable, teen gender, age, & race.

outcome.title: Count of Teen-parent Communications Regarding Health Risks Associated With Sex
outcome.description: Parent-teen communications score regarding health risks with sex were based upon two items: discussion that sex can result in pregnancy (y=1/n=0) and sex can result in sexually transmitted infections (y=1/n=0). Range is 0-2. Higher scores represent a better outcome.
outcome.population: Each row represents a different follow-up time period and the number of respondents varied across the time periods.

group.title: Smart Choices 4 Teens
group.description: A web-based intervention consisting of 3 main components (Communication, Alcohol, Relationships) provided to both parents and teens was completed by parents and teens individually. A probit analysis predicting completion was conducted from baseline measures and an instrumental variable, inverse Mills' ratio (IMR) representing the underlying selection processes was included as a covariate accounting for factors related to program completion. All controls were assigned 0 dosage.
analysis.estimate_desc: controlling for condition (experimental vs. control) , IMR, baseline measure of outcome variable, teen gender, age, & race.

outcome.title: Count of Parental Dating Rules
outcome.description: Parental rules regarding dating were based upon summing the yes (=1) response to 15 possible rules: parents must meet date, check in/call during date, parents must know destination, parents must know change of plans, address and phone number needed for parties, no dates on school nights, no sex, no sigle dates, curfew, only agreed upon locations, use good judgment, be gentleman/lady, leave if uncomfortable (y=1/n=0). Range is 0-15. Higher scores represent better outcomes.
outcome.population: There are 3 follow-up periods and the numbers analyzed vary across these follow-up periods

outcome.title: Count of Teens Who Have Ever Had Sex Over Their Lifetime
outcome.description: Have you ever had sex (vaginal, oral, or anal)? (responses were yes=1/no=0). Range was 0-1. Higher score is worse outcome risk.
outcome.population: The three rows reflect different follow-up periods, teens were lost to follow-up in subsequent waves

reported_events.time_frame: Over three years of the study
reported_events.desc: None of the parents or teens were exposed to any experimental condition that threatened life. There was not physical or medical intervention. This was a prevention program that was designed to address behavioral health issues.

group.title: Smart Choices 4 Teens
group.description: A web-based intervention consisting of 3 main components (Communication, Alcohol, Relationships) provided to both parents and teens was completed by parents and teens individually. At the end of each component, discussion guidelines were given to promote communications and to offer skill building practices between parent and teen regarding the component topic. Both the parent and teen were required to complete the component and discussion before moving to the next component. Smart Choices 4 Teens: This is a web-based prevention program designed to convey information about alcohol and relationships and the types of choices that they are making regarding these topics. General communications was another core element of the program that provided parents and teens with some key elements of talking to each other.

group.title: Control Condition
group.description: This group was provided with websites where information was available regarding the same topics.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: This sample was drawn from a nationwide sample of families compiled by panel vendors. Smart Choices 4 Teens is family-based, designed to promote healthy choices by teens related to alcohol use and relationships. It is not a treatment program.
